text: I'm very interested right now in
position base content where you have to
be in a certain position in space to
recognize something I kind of love the
idea of hiding it a bit the
installations that I've done on Bond
Street have been sort of two tributes
one was to Steve Jobs and the other to
David Bowie someone can walk by it and
see one side and if they're really
engaged they look back and then they get
surprised by the second element coming
back once I get the image I print it out
and then I might fragment it into slices
I put it onto basically like a sticker
and then I put it on on the fence the
Steve Jobs installations stayed there
for years I didn't ask the building if I
could do it I kind of did it at night he
has forever changed the way we connect
with each other connect with the world
even connect with ourselves and
creativity my wife is a very huge fan of
David Bowie which very much had an
impact on me I think his work is
transcending his life
I did black and white to color and III
thought that that was a very nice sort
of contrast I love the idea that it's
always a living and breathing experience
that people can just come up on to I
don't really consider myself a street
artist
I activate overlooked spaces in the
urban environment so the specific works
that I'm currently focusing on are in
elevator shaft ways where I retrofit
existing elevator cars there are windows
that are constructed or transparent
panels so you can see the surface behind
as you're riding and moving you start to
see that content we've thought that this
was the opportunity to sort of bring art
from the street back into a building and
kind of breathe sort of a new life or
new energy into the space
I work a lot
three-dimensionally with my hands
building models I'll build models of the
elevator shafts in physical form not
digital currently investigating how to
fragment an image around a 30 foot
mechanical enclosure on top of a 24 25
story building one thing I'm currently
really excited about using and I use
them a lot in the elevator installations
is mirrors and reflections to subtract
our sense of space and form my eye has
always been sort of following street art
I wasn't interested in defacing anything
or or making my mark it is a pleasure to
even as I'm walking out my door see
people clustered around it or or
grabbing other people you got to see it
from this angle and I want to engage
people
